subject: CHRISTIANS as SAINTS
reflection:
Christians: even before they enter the kingdom of light in
heaven, are people who let the light of the Gospel shine
through in their lives. In all they say and do-and in all
the evil things they leave undone-they give evidence of
their commitment to God, the Father of lights. How do people
become saints who let the light shine through? It begins
when the Holy Spirit enlightens them through the Gospel and
Holy Baptism, bring them to faith in Jesus Christ, as their
Savior. To declare Christian as bona fide saints is not to
say that they are perfect. They are sinners still because of
their continuing spiritual weakness. But sin does not rule
their lives; Jesus Christ does.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, sanctify us through Your Word and truth,
and fill us with the power of Your Holy Spirit. Help us to
live lives that reflect Your holiness, shining as lights in
the world even amidst spiritual weakness. May our faith
remain firm in Jesus Christ, who rules over sin and leads us
to eternal life. Amen. (AI)

subject: FISHING FOR PEOPLE
reflection:
The fish symbol ICHTHYS is an abbreviation confession of
faith-shorthand for the Greek Isus Christos Theou Hyios
Soter: Jesus Christ, Son of God, Savior. The fish symbol is
fitting because Jesus drew His first disciples from
fishermen, from two sets of brothers: Peter and Andrew and
James and John. Of course we know, fish were used in some of
His miracles. As called and commissioned apostles, Peter and
the others went into the world as fishers of people to let
down the net of the Gospel, and they were effective. “The
disciples went out and preached everywhere, and the Lord
worked with them and confirmed His Word by the signs that
accompanied it” (Mark 16:20). The ICHTHYS symbol is a reminder
that Jesus Christ is our Savior calling us to be fishers of
people and “to give an answer to everyone who asks you to
give the reason for the hope you have” (I Peter 3:15).
prayer:
Lord Jesus, You called Your disciples to be fishers of
people, drawing many into Your saving grace. Help us to
carry the ICHTHYS confession of faith boldly in our hearts,
sharing the hope we have in You with those around us. May we
be faithful apostles in our time, spreading Your Word and
living as witnesses of Your love and salvation. Amen. (Al)

*Today’s Verse:*

*“come, follow Me,” Jesus said, “and I will make you*

*fishers of men.” *(Mk. 1:17)



*Food for Thought:*

The fish symbol ICHTHYS is an abbreviation confession

of faith—shorthand for the Greek *Isus Christos Theou*

*Hyios Soter**: * Jesus Christ, Son of God, Savior.

The fish symbol is fitting because Jesus drew His first

disciples from fishermen, from two sets of brothers:

Peter and Andrew and James and John. Of course we

know, fish were used in some of His miracles.

As called and commissioned apostles, Peter and the

others went into the world as fishers of people to let

down the net of the Gospel, and they were effective.

“The disciples went out and preached everywhere,

and the Lord worked with them and confirmed His

Word by the signs that accompanied it” (Mk 16:20).

The ICHTHYS symbol is a reminder that Jesus Christ

is our Savior calling us to be fishers of people and

*“to give an answer to everyone who asks you to*

*give the reason for the hope you have” *(I Pet. 3:15).

*Pastor Al*

subject: GOD'S SIGN THROUGH NATURE
reflection:
How Good Are We At Interpreting Signs? For most of recorded
history, the world’s principal occupation was farming. The
farmer depended directly on the weather for his livelihood.
He needed just the right amount of sunshine and rain, to
make his living, and he grew skilled at interpreting natural
signs. Jesus was announcing an earthshaking event that would
be much more important than the year’s crops-the coming of
God’s Kingdom. Just as dark clouds forewarned of a
rainstorm, there were signs that the Kingdom would soon
arrive. But Jesus’ hearer’s though skilled at interpreting
weather signs, were intentionally ignoring the signs of the
times.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, open our eyes to see the signs of the times that
point to Your coming Kingdom. Help us not to ignore or
reject these signs but to prepare our hearts and lives to
welcome You. Grant us the wisdom and faith to live in
anticipation, trusting in Your promises and living according
to Your will. Amen. (Al)

*Verse for Today:*

Jesus said: *“When you see a cloud rising in the west,*

*immediately you say, ‘it’s going to rain,’ and it does.”*

(Lk. 12:54)



*How Good Are We At Interpreting Signs?*

For most of recorded history, the world’s principal

occupation was farming. The farmer depended

directly on the weather for his livelihood. He needed

just the right amount of sunshine and rain, to make

his living, and he grew skilled at interpreting natural

signs. Jesus was announcing an earthshaking event

that would be much more important than the year’s

crops—the coming of God’s Kingdom. Just as dark

clouds forewarned of a rainstorm, there were signs

that the Kingdom would soon arrive. But Jesus’

hearer’s though skilled at interpreting weather signs,

were intentionally ignoring the signs of the times.

*Pastor Al*

subject: PETER REED AND ROCK
reflection:
The apostle Peter was inconsistent in his relationship to
Jesus. He was impetuous, restless, and unstable. His worst
moment came, when he denied knowing Jesus despite his boast:
“Even if I have to die with You, I will never disown You”
(Mark 14:31). But Peter was also a rock, firm and solid. When
Jesus asked His disciples after hearing what others thought
of Him “Who do you say I am?” Peter answered. “You are the
Christ, the Son of the living God.” On that point Peter
never wavered. How can we become rock-solid in our faith? .
. . The Word of God and His means of grace will strengthen
our faith in Christ and make us into “a pillar in the temple
of my God” (Revelation 3:12).
prayer:
Lord Jesus, like Peter, help us to move beyond our doubts
and failures through the power of Your Spirit. Strengthen
our faith through Your Word and the means of grace, making
us firm and unwavering pillars in Your temple. May our lives
reflect Your love and courage, standing boldly for You in
every circumstance. Amen. (AI)

*Today’s Verse:*

*Simon Peter answered, “You are the Christ, the Son*

*of the living God.” *(Mt. 16:16)



*Some food for Thought:*

The apostle Peter was inconsistent in his relationship

to Jesus. He was impetuous, restless, and unstable. His

worst moment came, *when he denied knowing Jesus*

*despite his boast:* “Even if I have to die with You, I

will never disown You” (Mk. 14:31). *But* Peter was

also a rock, firm and solid. When Jesus asked His

disciples after hearing what others thought of Him

“Who do you say I am?” Peter answered. “You are

the Christ, the Son of the living God.” On that point

Peter never wavered.

How can we become rock-solid in our faith? *. . . *The

Word of God and His means of grace will strengthen

our faith in Christ and make us into “a pillar in the

temple of my God” (Rev. 3:12).

*Pastor Al*

subject: THANKFULNESS OUR FIRST PRIORITY
reflection:
During a time of great evil and injustice, (sounds a little
like now doesn’t it?): David was grateful that God is just
and fair. I imagine we have all wondered how many honest
people there are left in the world, but we can be assured
and thankful that God will continue to bring justice and
fairness when we involve Him in our activities. If you ever
feel you are being treated unfairly, ask the One who is
always fair and just to be with you. Then thank Him for His
presence. (read Isaiah 42:1-6)
prayer:
Heavenly Father, in times of injustice and uncertainty, we
are grateful that You are the just and fair Judge who brings
righteousness to the world. Help us to trust Your perfect
justice and involve You in all our activities, knowing You
are always with us in every circumstance. Thank You for Your
presence that comforts and strengthens us to face whatever
comes our way. Amen. (Al)

*Verse for Today:*

*I will thank the Lord because He is just: I will sing *

*praises to the name of the Lord Most High. *(Ps. 7:17)



*Give This Verse Some Thought:*

During a time of great evil and injustice, (sounds a

little like now doesn’t it?): David was grateful that

God is just and fair. I imagine we have all wondered

how many honest people there are left in the world,

*but* we can be assured *and* thankful that God will

continue to bring justice and fairness when we involve

Him in our activities. If you ever feel you are being

treated unfairly, ask the One who is always fair and

just to be with you. *Then thank Him for His presence.*

(read Isa. 42:1-6)


This month is going to be about all the things we should

give thanks for.

*Pastor Al*

subject: THANKFULNESS OUR FIRST PRIORITY
reflection:
I don’t like to complain, but too often we complain about
our problems to anyone who will listen and praise God only
in private. How much better it would be for us if we
complained in private and praised God in public. Let us
remember, to not only make this month but every month a time
of thankfulness as our first priority.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, help us to reverse our habits by praising
You openly and joyfully in public, letting our voices and
lives proclaim Your goodness. May our thankfulness overflow
beyond the private moments, reflecting Your greatness to all
who see and hear us. Teach us to make gratitude our foremost
priority every day. Amen. (AI)

subject: REMEMBERING TO ALWAYS GIVE THANKS
reflection:
Sometimes our security makes us feel invincible. The problem
is we forget that all things come from God. Let us not
become trapped by a false security that can be shattered.
Let us put our dependence in God, giving Him thanks for all
He provides.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, remind us that all security and blessings
come from You alone. Help us to put our full dependence on
You, giving thanks for Your constant provision and
protection. Guard us from false confidence in worldly things
and teach us to trust in Your faithful care each day. Amen.
(AI)

subject: REWARDING TRUE THANKFULNESS
reflection:
God is not deaf, dumb, or blind to wickedness. He patiently
awaits our response. There are some Bible translators who
say: “orders his way,” as referring to (showing the fruit of
faith.) The end result is that, there is nothing which the
citizens of heaven more love to look upon; and there is
nothing more agreeable to the eyes of our Heavenly Father.
How does our Heavenly Father judge your faith?
prayer:
Heavenly Father, Your faithful love is shown through the
fruit of faith evident in our lives. Thank You for patiently
waiting for us to respond and for delighting in the faith
that orders our way. Help us to live with genuine faith that
pleases You, bearing love, mercy, and good works that
reflect Your glory. Judge us not by empty words or actions,
but by the true fruit that grows from a heart fully
committed to You. Amen. (AI)

*Today’s Verse:*

*The one who offers thanksgiving as his sacrifice*

*glorifies Me; the one who orders his way rightly*

*I will show the salvation of God. *(Ps. 50:23)



*Food for Thought:*

God is not deaf, dumb, or blind to wickedness.

He patiently awaits our response. There are

some Bible translators who say: “*orders his way,”*

as referring to (*showing the fruit of faith*.) The

end result is that, there is nothing which the

citizens of heaven more love to look upon; and

there is nothing more agreeable to the eyes of

our Heavenly Father. *How does our Heavenly*

*Father judge your faith?*

* Pastor Al*

The one who offers thanksgiving as his sacrifice glorifies
Me; the one who orders his way rightly I will show the
salvation of God.

subject: GIVING SINCERE THANKS TO OUR CREATOR
reflection:
If we are totally honest I believe we would all have to say,
we struggle to come into God’s presence with the excitement
and humility that is spoken of in Psalm 95. But thankfully
the palmist directs us to not self-generate emotions but to
remember the God we worship. He is our Creator, who has
formed and protected us by his strong hands. And much
more-He is our Good Shepherd, who has made us the sheep of
His loving hands. Dear Lord lead us into your presence with
thanksgiving and joy.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, as the psalmist of Psalm 95 invites us, lead us
to come into Your presence with thanksgiving and joyful
praise. Help us to worship You with hearts full of
gratitude, recognizing You as our Creator and Good Shepherd
who lovingly guides and protects us. May our worship be
sincere and filled with joy, drawing us closer to You each
day. Amen. (AI)

*Let us come into His presence with thanksgiving;*

*let us make a joyful noise to Him with songs of*

*praise. *(Ps. 95:2)



*Food for Thought:*

If we are totally honest I believe we would all have

to not self-generate emotions *but* to remember the

and protected us by his strong hands. *And* much

more—He is our Good Shepherd, who has made us

the sheep of His loving hands. *Dear Lord lead us into*

*your presence with thanksgiving and joy.*

*Pastor Al*

subject: HAVING AN ATTITUDE OF THANKS AND PRAISE
reflection:
“Enter His gates with thanksgiving, and His courts with
praise.” (this to me is even speaking of the church today)
The emphasis is that this is God’s place. I remember my
mother talking about her dad, how he would make all her
brothers remove their caps when they entered through the
gates of the church yard; because it was God’s holy place.
How unfortunate it is that we have lost this respect for
God’s property, and often for God Himself. Let this be our
prayer: “Fill us with joyful praise and thanksgiving as we
seek to serve you!"
prayer:
Lord, restore in us a holy reverence for Your house and Your
presence. Fill our hearts with thankful praise as we enter,
our lips with worship, and our lives with service that
honors You. Teach us to treat what is Yours with joy,
gratitude, and awe. Amen. (AI)

for God’s property, and often for God Himself. Let

this be our prayer: “*Fill us with joyful praise and *

*thanksgiving as we seek to serve you!”*

* Pastor Al*

subject: GIVING THANKS FOR BEING INCLUDED
reflection:
An outreach to the Gentiles is not unique to the N.T. we
also see it in Isaiah 49:6 and many other O.T. passages.
Although God chose us “before the foundation of the world”
(Ephesians 1:4), His choice was not arbitrary. He chose us to be
save by Christ and in union with Christ, who Himself is
God’s “Chosen One” (Luke 9:35). Thank God that He chose us in
Love, not anger or judgment.
prayer:
Father, thank You for choosing us in love before the
foundation of the world and uniting us to Christ, Your
Chosen One. Open our eyes to Your heart for the nations, and
make us faithful witnesses who carry Your light to every
people. Let Your mercy shape our gratitude, our worship, and
our mission today. Amen. (AI)

*Today’s Verses*

*The Lord spoke, “I have made you a light for the*

*Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends*

*of the earth.”—and when the Gentiles heard this*

*they began rejoicing and glorifying the Word of*

*the Lord. *(Acts 13:47, 48a)



*Food for Thought:*

An outreach to the Gentiles is not unique to the

N.T. we also see it in Isa. 49:6 and many other O.T.

passages. Although God chose us “before the

foundation of the world” (Eph. 1:4), His choice

was not arbitrary. He chose us to be save by

Christ and in union with Christ, who Himself is

God’s “Chosen One” (Lk. 9:35). *Thank God that *

*He chose us in Love, not anger or judgement.*

* Pastor Al*
verse_text: For this is what the Lord has commanded us: 'I have made you a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.
original_verse_text: For this is what the Lord has commanded us: 'I have made you a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.
original_reflection_text:
An outreach to the Gentiles is not unique to the N.T. we
also see it in Isaiah 49:6 and many other O.T. passages.
Although God chose us “before the foundation of the world”
(Ephesians 1:4), His choice was not arbitrary. He chose us to be
save by Christ and in union with Christ, who Himself is
God’s “Chosen One” (Luke 9:35). Thank God that He chose us in
Love, not anger or judgment.

subject: THANK GOD FOR HIS WITNESSES
reflection:
Paul was sent to the Greeks and barbarians, to the wise and
the foolish. Today, we may be tempted to keep the Gospel to
ourselves or limit it to people like us. But Jesus did not
limit His work. He redeemed the whole world-even Barbarians
and fools like us. He has commissioned us to reach out to
all people. So let us remember to thank our Heavenly Father
for trusting us to be His witnesses.
prayer:
Heavenly Father, thank You that the Gospel is for all
people—wise and foolish, near and far—and that You have
entrusted us to be Your witnesses. Break every boundary in
our hearts, and give us bold love to reach those unlike us
with the good news of Jesus. Fill us with gratitude,
courage, and compassion as we go. Amen. (AI)

subject: THANKS FOR HIS INEXPRESSIBLE GIFT
reflection:
Paul urges the Corinthians to go with the flow of God’s
self-giving in Christ by giving themselves to others, so
that the downward and outward movement of grace comes full
circle in the free flow of thanksgiving. Seeing things in an
earthly, me-first way is miserly and petty. Instead, we
should open our hands and heats to receive God and extend
them to give our neighbor. Let us be generous in every way
that others will give thanks to God for us.
prayer:
Generous God, draw me into the self-giving flow of
Christ—open my hands to receive Your grace and open my heart
to pour it out for others. Free me from me-first thinking;
make me rich in generosity so that thanksgiving overflows to
You through many. Let my giving reflect Your love and lead
my neighbor to praise Your name. Amen. (AI)

*Today’s Verse:*

*You will be enriched in every way to be generous*

*In every way, which through us will produce *

*Thanksgiving to God. *(II Cor. 9:11)



*Food for Thought:*

Paul urges the Corinthians to go with the flow of God’s

self-giving in Christ by giving themselves to others, so

that the downward and outward movement of grace

comes full circle in the free flow of thanksgiving. Seeing

things in an earthly, me-first way is miserly and petty.

Instead, we should open our hands and heats to receive

God and extend them to give our neighbor.

*Let us be generous in every way that others will give*

*thanks to God for us.*

*Pastor Al*

subject: BEGIN WITH THANKSGIVING
reflection:
Paul urges us to adopt practices of living that are in
harmony with the Creator’s will. The strength and clarity of
this exhortation reminds us that we often set our minds on
those things that are contrary to God’s will. Paul’s
exhortations are always followed by promises of God’s
blessings on our behalf. So remember that, a prayer without
thanksgiving is an unfinished prayer.
prayer:
Father, align my thoughts and habits with Your will, and
turn my mind from anything that opposes Your ways. As I seek
to obey, fill my heart with gratitude so my prayers are
complete—with thanksgiving for Your faithful promises and
blessings. Let Your peace guard my heart as I walk in Your
truth today. Amen. (AI)

*The Lord is at hand; do not be anxious about*

*anything, but in everything by prayer and *

*supplication with thanksgiving let your *

*requests be made known to God. *(Phil. 4:5b-6)



*Thoughts for Today:*

are in harmony with the Creator’s will. The

strength and clarity of this exhortation

reminds us that we often set our minds on

those things that are contrary to God’s will.

Paul’s exhortations are always followed by

promises of God’s blessings on our behalf.

*So remember that, a prayer with-out *

*thanksgiving is an unfinished prayer.*

* Pastor Al*

subject: LIVING PROOF OF TRUE LOVE
reflection:
[Give thanks] We are urged to give thankful praise to God
for His goodness in Himself and as expressed in His works of
creation and redemption in this psalm. His steadfast love is
repeated in every verse in this psalm which emphasizes God’s
grace that is apparent, with all of His works. Here lies the
proof of God's love.
prayer:
God of steadfast love, we give You thankful praise for Your
goodness revealed in creation and redemption. Your grace is
apparent in all Your works, and Your faithful love endures
forever. Fill our hearts with gratitude for the countless
proofs of Your love, and let our lives be a continual
offering of praise to You. Amen. (AI)

subject: TRULY THANKFUL
reflection:
[rooted and built up] Both descriptions, one from nature and
the other from construction, point to something that is firm
and enduring. God’s Word makes this way of life possible.
This should cause us to be truly thankful.
prayer:
Lord, root me deeply in Your truth and build my life upon
Your unshakable Word. Make my faith firm and enduring, and
fill my heart with true gratitude for the strength You
provide. Let my daily walk reflect the stability and grace
that come from You alone. Amen. (AI)

subject: AN EXAMPLE TO FOLLOW
reflection:
The question that is often asked, “what is the good Life?”
‘is it prosperity, popularity, pleasure?” NO it is the life
we receive from Jesus, including gifts that we cannot make
or purchase: forgiveness, love, peace, and thankfulness.
Jesus’ life fills us with virtues rather than vices and
enables us to be a blessing rather than a ruin to others.
Before the dawning of the final day let sin’s dark deeds be
gone!
prayer:
Lord Jesus, thank You that the good life is Your life in
us—gifts we cannot buy: forgiveness, love, peace, and a
thankful heart. Drive out the dark deeds of sin and fill me
with Your virtues, that I may be a blessing and not a burden
to others. Let Your light dawn in me today and lead me in
the way of life. Amen. (AI)

*Whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in *

*the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the*

*Father through Him. *(Col. 3:17)



*Thoughts for Today:*

The question that is often asked, “what is the good

it is the life we receive from Jesus, including gifts

that we cannot make or purchase: forgiveness,

love, peace, and *thankfulness*. Jesus’ life fills us with

virtues rather than vices and enables us to be a blessing

rather than a ruin to others. *Before the dawning of *

*the final day let sin’s dark deeds be gone!*

* Pastor Al*

subject: TRUE GRATEFULNESS
reflection:
Thoughts from Matthew Henry: When Matthew Henry was robbed,
that very night he prayed: “I thank Thee, first because I
was never robbed before; second, because although they took
my purse, they did not take my life; third, because although
they took my all, it was not much; and fourth, because it
was I who was robbed, and not I who robbed.” Let us practice
this type of attitude.

in difficult circumstances. When trials come, help me to
trust Your sovereignty and count my blessings rather than my
losses. Shape my heart to be thankful for Your protection,
provision, and the privilege of integrity, even when life is
hard. Amen. (AI)

who robbed.” *Let us practice this type of attitude. *

subject: THANKFULNESS COMES FROM THE HEART
reflection:
From An Embarrassed Waitress: A young girl sat at the
counter of an ice cream store. “How much is an ice cream
Sunday?” she asked. “Fifty cents,” the waitress answered
with hardly a glance at the child. The girl opened her fist
and counted her coins. She asked, “how much is a dish of
plain ice cream?” Annoyed, the waitress snapped, “thirty
five cents!” The girl counted out 35 cents and handed it to
the waitress. “I’ll take the plain Ice cream.” The waitress
took the money without a word and brought the ice cream.
After the small customer had eaten and left, while the
waitress was cleaning up, suddenly became flushed with
shame. There, neatly beside the dish were two nickels and
five pennies-her tip. What kind of heart do you have?
prayer:
Lord, give me a humble and attentive heart that notices the
worth of every person, especially the small and overlooked.
Form in me kindness, patience, and generous love, so my
actions honor others as You do. Make my everyday encounters
a quiet witness to Your grace. Amen. (AI)

subject: IF YOU THINK YOU MUST THANK
reflection:
Sir Moses Montefiore, the Jewish philanthropist, had as is
motto, “Think and Thank.” In the old Anglo-Saxon,
thankfulness means “thankfulness.” Thinking of all God’s
goodness draws forth gratitude. The question is: Has your
attitude brought forth gratitude?
prayer:
God of goodness, help me to pause and think deeply on all
You have done, so that my heart overflows with true
gratitude. Let my attitude be shaped by thankfulness, and
may my words and actions reflect praise for Your constant
care. Make me mindful to “think and thank” You each day.
Amen. (AI)

subject: THINK OF THOSE WHO HAVE LESS THAN YOU
reflection:
A mother and her two children were destitute. In the depth
of winter they were nearly frozen, and so the mother took
the cellar door off its hinges and set it up in front of the
corner where they crouched down to sleep so that some of the
draft and cold might be kept from them. One of the children
whispered to her, “Mother, what do those do who have no
cellar door to put up in front of them?” Have you ever
thanked God for your many blessings and prayed for those who
have less than you?
prayer:
Gracious Provider, thank You for the blessings I too often
take for granted—shelter, warmth, and daily provision. Open
my heart to remember those with less, and move me to pray
and act with compassion. May I trust Your promise to supply
every need, and be generous in sharing with others. Amen.
(AI)

subject: FINDING THE BLESSINGS OF LIFE
reflection:
If we were given a dish of sand, and told there were
particles of iron in it, we might look for them with our
clumsy fingers and be unable to detect them. But if we were
given a magnet, to sweep through the sand, it would draw the
most invisible particles to itself. The thankless heart is
like our clumsy fingers, in the sand, it discovers no
mercies, but let the thankful heart sweep the day, and as
the magnet finds the iron, so the thankful heart will find
some heavenly blessings. Let us take time once again this
Thanksgiving Season, to examine our heart.
prayer:
Lord, give me a thankful heart that finds Your blessings in
every moment, just as a magnet draws hidden treasures from
the sand. Help me to remember and count Your mercies, even
when they are not obvious. Let gratitude shape my outlook
and fill my days with praise for all You have done. Amen.
(AI)

*Today's Food for Thought:*

If we were given a dish of sand, and told there were

particles of iron in it, we might look for them with our

clumsy fingers and be *unable* to detect them. But if

we were given a magnet, to sweep through the sand,

it would draw the most invisible particles to itself. The

*thankless* heart is like our clumsy fingers, in the sand,

it discovers no mercies, but let the *thankful heart*

sweep the day, and as the magnet finds the iron, so

the thankful heart will find some heavenly blessings.

*Let us take time once again this Thanksgiving Season, *

*to examine our heart*.

*Pastor Al.*

subject: EMBARRASSING THANKLESS PEOPLE
reflection:
One morning a mother took her three children to a restaurant
for breakfast. The smallest of the three children sat at the
very end of the row. She saw that other people began eating
as soon as they were served without stopping to give thanks.
When the food was served to her, she shouted out to her
mother: “Mommy, don’t people ask the blessing in this
place?” You can imagine the embarrassment of those present.
Her mother tried to hush her. But the waitress said to
little Mary, “Yes we do, sister! You give thanks!”
Amazingly, at that very moment everybody else also bowed
their heads and offered thanks. Embarrass them and maybe you
will bring them to their senses to say, “Thank You God.”
prayer:
Father, give us childlike courage to pause and bless You
openly, that our gratitude might awaken thanksgiving in
others. Teach us to honor You before every meal and in every
moment, remembering that all we have comes from Your hand.
Let public thankfulness become a gentle witness to Your
goodness. Amen. (AI)

subject: HARVEST OF THE HEART AT THANKSGIVING
reflection:
Paul uses the illustration of our being rooted in Christ.
Just as plants draw their nourishment from the soil through
their roots, so we draw our life-giving strength from
Christ. The more we draw our strength from Him, the less we
will be fooled by those who falsely claim to have lives
answers. While we are in the season of remembering let us
pause to praise and pray giving thanks from our hearts.
prayer:
Lord Jesus, root me deeply in You, that I may draw strength,
wisdom, and life from Your presence. Guard my heart from
deception and anchor me in Your truth, as I pause to praise
and give thanks with all my heart. Let gratitude and
steadfast faith flourish in me like a well-watered tree.
Amen. (AI)

subject: IN ALL THINGS
reflection:
Gratitude is what always spoils life when it is left out. A
thankful spirit enables one to praise God even when
circumstances are difficult. Alexander Whyte, a Scottish
preacher, always began his prayers with an expression of
gratitude. One cold, miserable day his people wondered what
he would say. He prayed, “We thank Thee, O Lord, that it is
not always like this.” Yes, we always have something to be
thankful for.
prayer:
Lord, give me a thankful spirit that finds Your goodness
even in hard days. Teach me to praise You not because
circumstances are easy, but because You are faithful—and to
remember, with gratitude, that it will not always be like
this. Let thanksgiving color my words, steady my heart, and
honor Your name. Amen. (AI)

reflection:
Count your blessings instead of your crosses. Count your
gains instead of your losses. Count your joys instead of
your woes. Count your friends instead of your foes. Count
your smiles instead of your tears. Count your courage
instead of your fears. Count your full years instead of your
lean. Count your kind deeds instead of your mean. Count your
health instead of your wealth. Count on God instead of
yourself, and it will give you much to be thankful for!

the joys, kindness, and courage You provide each day. Help
me to trust in You rather than myself, remembering Your
faithfulness through every season. Fill my heart with
gratitude and open my eyes to all I have to be thankful for.
Amen. (AI)

subject: THE ART OF THANKSGIVING
reflection:
Taking Inventory: The art of thanksgiving is, thanks-living.
It is gratitude in action. It is thanking God for, the gift
of life by living it triumphantly. It is thanking God for,
your talents and abilities by accepting them as, an
obligation to be invested for the common good. It is
thanking God for, all that men and women have done for you
by, doing things for others. It is thanking God for,
happiness by striving to make others happy. It is thanking
God for, beauty by helping to make the world more beautiful.
It is thanking God for, inspiration by trying to be an
inspiration to others. It is thanking God for, health and
strength by the care and respect you show your body.
prayer:
Giver of every good gift, teach me the art of
thanks-living—gratitude that moves my hands and feet. Help
me honor Your gifts by using them for the common good,
bringing joy where there is sorrow, beauty where there is
brokenness, and encouragement where there is weariness. Let
my care for my body, my service to others, and my daily
choices become a living thank You to You. Amen. (AI)

subject: WHY ONLY ONE DAY
reflection:
Charles Dickens said that we are somewhat mixed up here in
America-he told an audience that instead of having one
Thanksgiving Day each year we should have 364. “Use that one
day for complaining and griping,” he said. “We should use
the our 364 days to thank God for His many blessings, He has
showered upon us. I AGREE WITH THIS IDEA!
prayer:
Gracious God, turn my heart from grumbling to gratitude, not
just for a day but every day. Open my eyes to the countless
blessings You shower upon me, and teach me to give thanks in
all circumstances as an act of trust and worship. Let a
spirit of thanksgiving shape my words, my work, and my
witness. Amen. (AI)

*Verse for Today:*

*Therefore, if any one is in Christ, he is a*

*new creation; the old has gone, the new*

*has come!” *(II Cor. 5:17 NIV)



*Thought for Today:*

Through forgiveness the arms of Jesus

lift you, His blood cleanse you, and His

love changes you. It is His free gift to you.

Turn your heart to Jesus. Pray to receive

Him and His forgiveness by faith today. . .

He will come into your heart and make

all things new. *Do you have the joy of*

*being forgiven? *

* Pastor Al*
